questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a speech abnormality following a hemorrhagic stroke. He does not understand any written words or conversation. His speech is fluent but is incomprehensible. Repetition is also impaired.  Where is the lesion located?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, comprehension and repetition are impaired while the fluency is intact. This points to Wernicke’s aphasia. The area affected is Wernicke's area located in the superior temporal gyrus (marked 4). 

Broca’s motor speech area (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.

Related Pearl: Brodmann areas

Area of the Brain(Brodmann) Location
3, 1 and 2 - Primary sensory area

Postcentral gyrus

Extends to the posterior part of the paracentral lobule medially
4 - Primary motor area

Precentral gyrus

Extends to the anterior part of the paracentral lobule medially
6- Premotor area

Anterior to Area 4

In the posterior parts of superior, middle and inferior frontal gyri
5 and 7 - Sensory association area Superior parietal lobule
8 - Frontal eye field Posterior part of middle frontal gyrus, anterior to the facial area of the precentral gyrus
44 and 45 - Broca’s(Motor speech) area Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

41 and 42 - 

Primary auditory area

 Superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus(Heschl’s gyrus)
22* - Wernicke’s(Sensory speech) area Superior temporal gyrus
17 - Primary visual(striate) area Walls and floor of the posterior part of calcarine sulcus (postcalcarine sulcus) in the occipital lobe

18 and 19- 

Visual association area

 Remaining part of the medial and superolateral surfaces of the occipital lobe
28 - Primary olfactory area Anterior part of the parahippocampal gyrus and uncus
43 - Gustatory(taste) area Inferior part of the parietal lobe, posterior to the general sensory area of the mouth

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency
Wernicke's Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved
Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

questions.text: Spermatogenesis is maintained by which hormone?
questions.solution:
All three of them (testosterone, FSH, LH) are required for spermatogenesis.

Pulses of hypothalamic GnRH stimulate the anterior pituitary to secrete FSH and LH, which then act on the testes

FSH acts on the Sertoli cells to stimulate spermatogenesis and inhibin secretion. LH acts on the Leydig cells to stimulate testosterone secretion. Testosterone, acting locally on the Sertoli cells, is essential for maintaining spermatogenesis.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Northern blotting is used for detection of RNA.
  • Southern blotting is used for detection of DNA.
  • Western blotting is used for detection of protein.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with fever, pain, and swelling in the left mid-thigh region. X-ray shows the characteristic onion skin appearance. A biopsy from the lesion shows a small round cell tumor with PAS positivity as shown in the image. The most likely diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.

Image shows solid sheets of small uniform round cells with PAS-positive magenta pink colored cytoplasm characteristic of Ewing’s Sarcoma/PNET.

The cells of Ewing’s Sarcoma/PNET show PAS positivity due to the presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen.

This is an important feature for the differential diagnosis with other small round cell tumors. However, it is not very specific.

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is:
questions.solution: Parvovirus B19 infection mimics erythroblastosis fetalis. B19 is associated with erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), transient aplastic crisis, pure red cell aplasia, and erythroblastosis fetalis (most commonly in early pregnancy).

questions.text: A 56 year old female patient presented with breast carcinoma and she was prescribed trastuzumab. Which of the following statements regarding this drug is true?

choices.text: It is an antibody produced entirely from mouse containing no human component
It is a monoclonal antibody produced by injecting her-2 antigen
It is a monoclonal antibody containing only human component

questions.solution:
Trastuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the external domain of HER2/neu. It is indicated in the management of adjuvant therapy in early and metastatic HER-2 positive breast cancer. 

Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase receptor (HER-2-TK) inhibitors:

  • Lapatinib
  • Neratinib

Anti-Her-2 monoclonal antibodies:

  • Trastuzumab
  • Pertuzumab

Related Pearl: Monoclonal antibodies nomenclature

Murine - 0% human: “omab” (Tositumomab)

Chimeric - 65% human: “ximab” (Rituximab)

Humanized - 95% human: “zumab” (Trastuzumab)

Fully human - 100% human: “umab” (Adalimumab)

questions.text:
Which of the following indices are used to determine the sex of an individual?
  1. Intermembral index
  2. Sternal index
  3. Corporobasal sacral index
  4. Ischiopubic index
  5. Cephalic index
questions.solution:
Sternal index, corporobasal sacral index, and ischiopubic index are used to determine the sex of the individual.

The intermembral index and cephalic index are helpful in determining the race of the individual.

Indices for sex determination: 

Indices Calculation (x100) Male Female
Ischiopubic index Length of pubis/Length of ischium <90 >95
Corporobasal index Transverse diameter of body of S1 / Breadth of base of sacrum 40-50 35-45
Sciatic notch index Maximum breadth of greater sciatic notch / Maximum depth of greater sciatic notch 4-5 5-6
Sacral index Transverse diameter of base of sacrum / Length of sacrum <114 >114
Sternal index Length of manubrium / Length of mesosternum 32-85 44-80

 

Related Pearl: Indices for determination of race and sex of an individual

To determine the sex of an individual -

Krogman's degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80%

 

To determine the race of an individual -

questions.text: A patient presented with difficulty in breathing and swallowing. On examination, a painless nasopharyngeal mass was noted as shown in the image below. Angiofibroma was suspected. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a nasopharyngeal mass suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), which is causing difficulty in breathing and swallowing. It is more common in males. 

The tumor is predominantly seen in adolescent males in the second decade of life. It is thought to be testosterone dependent. Patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx which is activated to form angiofibroma when male sex hormones appear.

A biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of severe bleeding. The vessels lack contractile components and hence bleeding cannot be controlled with adrenaline.

questions.text: A 68-year-old lady is a known case of diabetes and is on insulin for the last 8 years. Her sugars are poorly controlled and now she complains of hazy vision. What type of cataract will be characteristically noted in her eyes?
questions.solution:
The typical appearance of a diabetic cataract is a snowflake cataract.

Hyperglycemia is reflected in a high level of glucose in the aqueous humor, which diffuses into the lens. Here, glucose is metabolized into sorbitol, which accumulates within the lens, resulting in secondary osmotic overhydration.

questions.text: During a school health survey on malnutrition, the children are arranged according to ascending order of their heights. This arrangement is made to obtain which of the following data?
questions.solution:
The 50th centile can be obtained when values are arranged in order and the central value is picked out. This is the same as the median.

In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.

In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.

An example of how to calculate the median of an odd and an even number of elements is given below.

Option C: Geometric mean is obtained by taking the arithmetic mean of values on a logarithmic scale.

Option D: Mean deviation is a measure of dispersion. The average of deviations from the arithmetic mean gives the mean deviation.

questions.text: An epidemiologist plans to conduct a prospective study instead of a retrospective study. Which of the following disadvantages does he aim to eliminate by conducting this study?
questions.solution:
Recall bias can be eliminated in a prospective study.

Memory or recall bias: When cases and controls are asked questions about their past history, it may be more likely for the cases to recall the existence of certain events or factors, than the controls who are healthy persons. For example, those who have had a myocardial infarction might be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events than those who have not. Thus cases may have a different recall of past events than controls.

Prospective studies begin in the present and continue into future. Hence there will be minimal change for recall bias.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

  • Bias due to confounding: It can be removed by matching.
  • Memory or recall bias as cases and controls may not be able to recall specifics about their history.
  • Selection bias: Cases and controls may not be representative of the population or there may be systematic differences between both.
  • Berkesonian bias: This type of selection bias occurs in hospital cases and controls as the admission rates for people with different diseases may differ.
  • Interviewer’s bias: If the interviewer knows the hypothesis and who the cases are, he/she may interview the cases more thoroughly than the controls. It can be eliminated by double blinding.
  • Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias: It is due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. For example, a case-control study is carried out to study the relation between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI), being cases interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: What is Hardy-Weinberg law related to?
questions.solution:
The Hardy-Weinberg law is related to population genetics. Population genetics is the study of the precise genetic composition of a population and various factors determining the incidence of inherited traits in them. 

Founder effect is a violation to this law. It is due to difference in expression of the genes in founding population. This is responsible for the difference in the distribution of disease in population.

Related Pearl: Hardy-Weinberg Law

  • The Hardy-Weinberg Law is related to population genetics.
  • It is based on the principle founded by G.H. Hardy and Wilhelm Weinberg.
  • The law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele tends to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of other evolutionary influences.
  • It is also called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium or principle.
  • It is only applicable for infinitely large, static populations which randomly mate.
  • This law fails in the following conditions:
    • Small and dynamic populations
    • Non random or assortative mating
    • Mutations
    • Gene outflow and genetic drift
    • Migration

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient, who is a known case of ovarian cancer, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is dermatomyositis.

The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. The clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with a rash in an elderly female, with a history of internal malignancy, is also suggestive of dermatomyositis. 

Other classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers

Facial rash in dermatomyositis-

Eyelid erythema/heliotrope rash in dermatomyositis-

V- sign in dermatomyositis-

Shawl sign in dermatomyositis-

Flagellate erythema in dermatomyositis-

Gottron papules in dermatomyositis-

Poikilodermatous changes in dermatomyositis-

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of lower extremity weakness. He initially noticed difficulty climbing the stairs and now he is unable to stand. He gives a history of bloody diarrhea a few weeks ago. The physician suspects a case of Guillain- Barre syndrome.  Which of the following are expected to be elevated in the CSF of this patient?
questions.solution:
Protein levels are elevated (100-1000mg/dl) in the CSF of a patient with Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS).

The CSF cell counts are usually normal. Pleocytosis (presence of an abnormally large number of lymphocytes in the cerebrospinal fluid) is usually not seen in GBS. Albuminocytologic dissociation, which is an elevation in CSF protein without an elevation in white blood cells, is characteristic in GBS.

Causes of albuminocytologic dissociation

  • Guillain-Barre Syndrome
  • Spinal cord tumours

questions.text: Treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia is
questions.solution:
Expectant management is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

Chemotherapy and monoclonal antibodies are used when there is

  • Progressive marrow failure- worsening anemia, thrombocytopenia
  • Progressive splenomegaly
  • Progressive lymphadenopathy
  • Presence of constitutional symptoms like weight loss, fever, night sweats, etc.

Important drugs used in the management of CLL are fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, bendamustine, and rituximab.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent epigastric pain with a burning sensation for the past 2 years. The pain usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food. He also says that he sometimes wakes up at night because of severe pain. The most probable cause for his symptoms is:
questions.solution:
Epigastric pain with burning sensation that usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food suggestive of duodenal ulcer.

The following patterns of pain are usually seen in peptic ulcer disease:

Duodenal Ulcer- Pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Pain may awaken the patient from sleep.

Gastric Ulcer- Pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.

Perforated ulcer- The bed of the ulcer tunnels through the entire thickness of the gastric wall and opens into the peritoneum. This presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and leads to peritonitis. Radiography shows gas under the diaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Meckel’s Diverticulum?

choices.text: Can be a lead point for intussusception
The most common presenting symptom is bleeding in younger children
Most common heterotropic tissue is Gastric Mucosa

questions.solution:
Meckel’s Diverticulum is true diverticulum containing all layers of intestine. Others are false diverticula.

Meckel’s Diverticulum:

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of vitelline duct during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation.
  • The rule of 2s:
    • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)
    • 2% incidence
    • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
    • approximately 2 inches long
    • Usually symptomatic by 2 years 
  • Most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children <5 years.
  • 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan is used to detect gastric mucosa.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy 

The following diagram shows the various anomalies that arise as a result of failure of normal regression of vitello-intestinal duct :

questions.text: Which of the following  treatment modalities  is used in symptomatic parathyroid hyperplasia involving all four glands?

choices.text: Removal of all the affected glands with lifelong calcium supplementation
Complete removal of three glands with partial resection of the less affected gland
Partial resection of the affected glands with autotransplantation of the less affected gland
Complete removal of three glands with ligation of inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
Hyperplasia involving all four parathyroid glands is treated by complete removal of three glands with partial resection of the less affected gland (~30 mg left as remnant)

Modes of treatment: 

  • Total cervical parathyroidectomy with immediate heterotopic transplantation of parathyroid tissue (usually the forearm)
  • Subtotal parathyroidectomy 

Subtotal Parathyroidectomy: 

Remnant left behind should be of the least affected parathyroid gland, and ideally be 30 mg (size of 1 parathyroid gland). A lower gland is preferred because its location reduces the risk of injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. 

Total Parathyroidectomy with heterotopic transplantation : 

When multiple parathyroids are resected, parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient with hypertension presented with a sudden tearing type of chest pain. A  CECT chest was done and is given below. What is the preferred treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Medical management with blood pressure control
Further diagnostic workup with transesophageal echocardiography

questions.solution:
The patient seems to be having an aortic dissection and CT chest indicates a Stanford Type A aortic dissection from the aortic root. He requires urgent surgical management.

The Stanford classification is used to separate aortic dissections into those that need surgical repair, and those that usually require only medical management. The Stanford classification divides dissections by the most proximal involvement.

Type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected. It requires urgent surgical management and may result in:

  • Coronary artery occlusion
  • Aortic incompetence
  • Rupture into the pericardial sac with resulting cardiac tamponade

Type B begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels and dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery affecting only the descending aorta. In these patients, initial treatment is medical management with blood pressure control.

The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:

  • Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta ( Stanford A)
  • Type II: involves ascending aorta only ( Stanford A)
  • Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery ( Stanford B)

Further diagnostic workup with TEE(transesophageal echocardiography) or MRA (magnetic resonance angiography) is not required as CT is showing ascending aorta dissection.

questions.text: What is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the first and second part of duodenum.

MEN 1 syndrome is characterized by the triad of tumors involving:

  • Parathyroids
  • Pancreatic islets
  • Anterior pituitary.

Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome.

Gastrinoma if associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcers is called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text:
A 23 yr old gravida 1, para 0 at 25 weeks gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. BP-104/72mm Hg, PR-72bpm.There is generalized edema. Peripheral smear shows hemolysis. Lab values are as follows:
Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3
Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
AST: 90 IU/L
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is HELLP syndrome.

The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, point towards a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Although related to preeclampsia, hypertension and proteinuria may be absent or minimal in HELLP syndrome.

Tennessee criteria used in the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome :

  • Platelet count <1 lakh,
  • AST >70 IU/L,
  • LDH >600 IU/L

Risk factors for HELLP syndrome include

  • Preeclampsia
  • abnormal placentation
  • family history of HELLP syndrome
  • elevated levels of fetal mRNA for FLT l (vascular endothelial growth factor rfi­ receptor 1) and
  • Multiparity
  • Maternal age >34 years
  • European descent
  • History of previous poor pregnancy outcomes

Laboratory evaluation in HELLP:

  • Complete blood cell (CBC) count: Thrombocytopenia, anemia with possible reticulocytosis
  • Coagulation studies: Normal prothrombin time, 50% may have prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes, helmet cells, and burr cells secondary to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase/alanine aminotransferase (AST/ALT) levels: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction
  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction or hemolysis
  • Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)/creatinine with acute renal failure
  • Bilirubin level: Increased secondary to hemolysis
  • Haptoglobin level: Decreased secondary to hemolysis
  • Fibrinogen levels: Low secondary to increased coagulation
  • D-dimer: Increased due to fibrinolysis/DIC

HELLP syndrome may lead to the development of DIC which manifests as increased fibrin split products and decreased fibrinogen levels.

Other options:

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text: While working as a JR in the department of pathology, you see the presence of signet ring cells in the microscopic examination of a resected ovarian mass specimen. Which of the following tumors you will mention in the report?
questions.solution:
Signet ring cells are seen in Krukenberg tumor.

Krukenberg tumor:

It is the carcinoma of stomach metastasised to ovary. The tumor is thought to spread via 1 of the 3 mechanisms:

  • The lymphatic system,
  • The hematogenous system, or
  • The transcoelomic pathway.

It is usually bilateral and they have a smooth surface and a waxy consistency. They retain the shape of a normal ovary.

Numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are distributed singly or in nests in a luteinized stroma (hematoxylin-eosin stain):

questions.text:
Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotypes.
Condition Karyotype
1. Turner's syndrome A. 46 + XX
2. Sweyer's syndrome B. 46+ XY
3. Androgen insensitivity syndrome C. 46+ XY
4. MRKH - Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome D. 45 + XO
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

MRKH syndrome (Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser)/ MURCS (Mullerian agenesis, renal aplasia, and cervicothoracic somite dysplasia)is a condition where the testes are absent. It has a Karyotype of 46 XX. So, the gonads present are ovaries (in contrast to androgen insensitivity syndrome where the testes are present). Vagina in its upper 2/3rd are absent but lower one-third is present as it develops from the urogenital sinus.

Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome/testicular feminizing syndrome:

In this syndrome, the karyotype is XY and thus, the patient is a genotypic male. Pathology is due to the defective response of the androgen receptors to androgens. Findings include:

  • Primary amenorrhea → Due to the absence of uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts → Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region → Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, caused by loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix → Due to the production of Mullerian inhibiting substance from the Sertoli cells of the testis.

Note:

There is some discrepancy among authors on this topic. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) with XY karyotype may have mostly female external sexual characteristics. According to William's Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition page 40, breast development occurs due to peripheral aromatization of testosterone to estrogen whereas the pubic and axillary hair remains scant or absent. But as per Shaw's Textbook of Gynecology, XY females with AIS have normal secondary sexual characteristics. 

Sweyer syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). The following features are seen: 

  • Normal prepubertal female phenotype- Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Normal Müllerian system development due to the absence of AMH. (Uterus and cervix present)
  • Female external genitalia
  • Presence of dysgenetic testes that cannot produce AMH or sex hormones. They have a risk of malignant transformation.

As there is gonadal dysgenesis in a patient with 46 XY karyotype, they are actually determined to be males and are a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. They present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters, and female external genitalia.

Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO). In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure that is hypogonadism. The clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: Treatment of choice for Kawasaki disease is:
questions.solution:
Treatment of choice in Kawaski disease is IV immunoglobulins. IV immunoglobulins along with aspirin have proven beneficial in preventing coronary artery abnormalities.

Tocilizumab is used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A man, after sleeping the whole night with his arm hanging over the back of the chair wakes up with an inability to extend his wrist. What is the mechanism behind this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
This is a case of saturday night palsy, which is a type of neuropraxia. 

Neuropraxia is a reversible physiological block in nerve conduction. Saturday night palsy occurs when radial nerve is compressed in the arm from direct pressure against a firm object. It can occur when the person sleeps on the arm, often after alcohol intoxication. Therefore, it is known as saturday night palsy or weekend palsy.

Other examples for neuropraxia include crutch palsy and tourniquet palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with pseudologia fantastica?
questions.solution:
Patients with Munchausen syndrome (factitious disorder) demonstrate pseudologia fantastica, a specific syndrome of autobiographical lying with four features:

  1. The stories are not entirely improbable and are built upon a basis of truth.
  2. The stories are enduring.
  3. They are not told purely for personal gain and have a self-aggrandizing quality.
  4. They are not delusions, in that the patient can admit to falsehoods when confronted with conflicting facts.

In pseudologia fantastica, limited factual material is mixed with extensive and colourful fantasies. The listener's interest pleases the patient and, thus, reinforces the symptom.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primi in her second trimester of pregnancy is posted for the open appendectomy. The ideal anesthetic technique for this surgery is _______
questions.solution:
Spinal anesthesia is preferred over other techniques for the appendectomy in the second trimester. Total anesthetic drug exposure is least with spinal anesthesia over others.

General anesthesia is associated with a greater risk of:

  • Pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents
  • Difficult or failed intubation
  • Drug exposure to the fetus

Epidural anesthesia has the risk of

  • Accidental intravascular injection
  • Accidental intrathecal injection

In general, spinal anesthesia is appropriate for open appendectomies and general anesthesia for laparoscopic appendectomies.

Related Pearl: Regional Anesthesia in Obstetrics

  • Pregnant patients display enhanced sensitivity to LA during regional anesthesia because of hormonal factors and engorgement of epidural venous plexus resulting in decreased epidural space and subarachnoid space (CSF volume).This enhances the cephalad spread of LA solution during spinal and epidural anesthesia.
  • Lower doses of LA agents and pain relief drugs are used because of altered pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics during parturition as a result of hormonal and cardiovascular effects.
  • Lignocaine is less protein bound and nerves are more sensitive to LA agents.
  • NOT a cause of decreased anesthetic requirement during pregnancy Increased lumbar lordosis.
  • The level of the block under spinal anesthesia is desirable upto T4.
  • Lumbar epidural - The most preferred technique for painless labor.

questions.text: Tinea incognito is due to _____
questions.solution:
Tinea incognito is an atypical clinical lesion of tinea, usually produced by incorrect treatment of fungal infection with a topical corticosteroid.

  • Steroids suppress inflammation without eliminating the fungus; so the typical raised margin is diminished, scaling is lost and inflammation reduces. Hence, diagnosis becomes difficult.
  • Treatment: Oral terbinafine or itraconazole

Pharmacological treatment of fungal Tinea infection is :

Localized disease, recent onset

  • Topical terbinafine twice daily for 2 weeks
  • Topical azole once or twice daily for 2–4 weeks

Widespread disease

  • First-line:
    Oral terbinafine 250 mg/day 2–3 weeks
    Oral Itraconazole 100 mg/day 2–4 weeks
  • Second line:
    Oral Griseofulvin 1 g/day for 4 weeks

questions.text: What is the most​ common site of hypertensive bleed in the brain?
questions.solution:
The most common site of hypertensive bleed in the brain is basal ganglia and putamen.

The most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhages is hypertension.

Following are the typical locations of ICH in order of decreasing frequency: 

  •   Basal ganglia hemorrhage (especially the putamen)
  •   Thalamic hemorrhage
  •   Pontine hemorrhage
  •   Cerebellar hemorrhage 

The investigation of choice in stroke is non-contrast CT.

The following image shows bleed in the basal ganglia:

questions.text: All of the following are uses of DMSA scan except:
questions.solution: Renal plasma flow can be only seen on the dynamic scan and DMSA cannot be used for this purpose.
